channel.title: Links on Dailey Missives
channel.description: Recent content in Links on Dailey Missives

item.title: Assorted Things
item.description:
1. The Mother Who Never Stopped Believing Her Son Was Still There
    What an incredible read, on so many levels.
  2. Think more about what to focus on - by Henrik Karlsson
  3. The Road to Campus Serfdom – John O. McGinnis
    “Ironically, the left, now alarmed by the federal government’s intrusive reach, bears direct responsibility for crafting the very legal weapons wielded against the universities it dominates.”
  4. Vibe Coding, Vibe Checking, and Vibe Blogging
    Using Generative AI for Personal-Scale Projects
  5. The Third Humbling of Humanity
    What will be left of our self-conception once artificial intelligence becomes better than us at writing poems or making movies?
  6. On Jagged AGI: o3, Gemini 2.5, and everything after
    I myself have noted the big difference in 2.5 pro and what came before.
  7. 🔍 Why I stopped angel investing after 15 years (and what I’m doing instead)
  8. Revolutionizing Dairy Farming: How Robots Benefit Cows & Farmers - IEEE Spectrum

item.title: Weekly Assorted Things
item.description:
1. Why Americans Are Working Less
  2. Unburying the Remains of the Third Reich
    As the German right ascends, the nation is still grappling with its fascist past — and how to handle its remains.
  3. How the American Medical Association Screws Doctors
  4. dltHub: ELT as Python Code
    Lightweight Python code to move data
  5. Meeting people. | Irrational Exuberance
  6. To future entrepreneurs in health tech | by Mark Cavage | Feb, 2025 | Medium
  7. FOSS infrastructure is under attack by AI companies

item.title: Weekly Assorted Things
item.description:
1. Intelligence and individual differences in astrological belief.
    “Of our psychological measures we find intelligence, as measured with Wordsum, to have the largest effect size, negatively predicting belief in astrology. Education also predicts disbelief, supporting the “superficial knowledge” hypothesis. Measures of religiosity and spirituality had null effects, in contradiction of the “metaphysical uncertainty” hypothesis that a need for metaphysical beliefs causes one to believe in astrology. We find that right-wing individuals are less likely to believe in astrology, in contradiction to Theodore W. Adorno’s “authoritarian” of astrology. We also find no effect scientific trust on astrological belief. “ Oof. Via Tyler Cowen.
  2. My LLM codegen workflow atm | Harper Reed’s Blog
    Really great overview. Golden age for indie devs?
  3. New York Times goes all-in on internal AI tools | Semafor
    From actively suing to actively using. Interesting pivot. As an NYT subscriber, I look forward to seeing how it pans out.
  4. AI Essentials for Tech Executives
    Lots of useful stuff here, particularly around testing.
  5. Run LLMs on macOS using llm-mlx and Apple’s MLX framework
    Leveraging Apple silicon. I will certainly hone this a spin on my machine.
  6. The Death of Government Expertise (The Atlantic)
    “Populists are generally wary of experts, especially those who work for the government, but Musk is no man of the people: He is the richest human being in the world, and he runs major companies that rely both on government-provided expertise and significant government subsidies. As my colleague Anne Applebaum wrote, “Musk has made no attempt to professionally audit or even understand many of the programs being cut”—a willful indifference that gives away the game.”

item.title: Weekly Assorted Things
item.description:
1. How Progressives Froze the American Dream
    “…. the freedom to choose one’s city or community has become a privilege of class.”
  2. The End of Programming as We Know It – O’Reilly
    Pretty much the best summary of where things are going. Of course I would like this, though – it confirms my biases.
  3. AI haters build tarpits to trap and trick AI scrapers that ignore robots.txt - Ars Technica
    I can’t help but find this somewhat amusing.
